title: Large Goiter Causing Airway Compression
setup_script: A 65-year-old woman presents with progressive dyspnea and dysphagia. She has a long-standing multinodular goiter that has enlarged over time. CT scan shows a substernal goiter compressing and deviating the trachea.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Obtain history focusing on compressive symptoms (dyspnea, dysphagia, voice changes) and risk factors (radiation exposure).
Perform physical exam noting neck mass, tracheal deviation, and evaluate for superior vena cava syndrome.
Order thyroid function tests and imaging (CT or MRI) to assess size, retrosternal extension, and airway compression.
Discuss indications for surgery: symptomatic compression, suspicion of malignancy, or hyperthyroidism.
Plan total or subtotal thyroidectomy; consider sternotomy if significant intrathoracic extension.
Assess airway preoperatively; coordinate with anesthesia for fiberoptic intubation or awake intubation if airway compromise.
Discuss surgical risks including RLN injury, hypoparathyroidism, hemorrhage, and need for sternotomy.
Perform surgery carefully dissecting retrosternal component and protecting parathyroids and nerves.
Ensure hemostasis and consider drain placement; monitor for neck hematoma postoperatively.
Postoperative management: monitor airway, calcium, and voice; provide hormone replacement if entire gland removed.
Pathology evaluation to rule out malignancy and document nodular goiter features.
Educate patient on signs of hypocalcemia and need for follow-up with endocrinology.

critical_decision_points: Evaluating severity of airway compression and planning airway management.
Deciding extent of surgery and possible need for sternotomy based on imaging.
Preserving vital structures during subtotal/total thyroidectomy.
Postoperative monitoring for hematoma and hypocalcemia.
Communicating operative risks and postoperative expectations.
